text: My wife and I stayed at Hotel Zocalo Central for a week in June. I chose this hotel because of a very positive previous experience years before. If anything, Hotel Zocalo Central was even better than the last time. Itâs a beautiful property a short walk from Plaza Central and a pedestrian mall lined with shops, restaurants, parks and museums. But itâs the staff that makes this hotel great. Here is an example. I had always wanted to see Lucha Libre, a colorful, dramatic and acrobatic Mexican version of WWE entertainment wrestling in the US. Emblematic of this Mexican form of wrestling, the Luchadores (wrestlers) wear colorful snug-fitting masks called mascaras. I asked at the desk, and they sent me to Leyka, the concierge. My last chance to attend Lucha Libre before we went home was at Arena Mexico the next evening. It was complicated to acquire a ticket and find a good seat at the last minute. Leyka took over and tracked down a ticket only five rows from ringside. I was so excited. The next day I stopped by to thank Leyka and she presented me with my own mascara de Luchador. It was as colorful and well-made as the ones worn by the Luchadores in the ring. That night I had such a great time. The pageantry of Lucha Libre features a Good vs Evil theme. The observers are very much involved in what's going on in the ring, and the arena throbbed with the passionate crowd. I feel very attached to Hotel Zocalo Central and will certainly stay there again.
dominant_topics_words: nice, great, amazing, place, food

text: I went last night with a friend. We didn't book, but they immediately seated us at a table near the view. It was beautiful, but unfortunately it was raining. We chose to choose from two menus. The first welcome course consisted of four different types of bread spread with local butter. Then we had a salad and a bruschetta with meat and cheese, both delicious. The second course consisted of two tacos, one with avocado and the other with fried fish (I don't like tacos, but they were excellent). The third course consisted of a plate of ravioli with cheese and the other fish on a bed of salsa and broccoli (both delicious). Finally, dessert was served, one with ice cream and avocado and the other with chocolate. We paid â¬45 each. Highly recommended, a wonderful place, fast and friendly staff.

text:
On a college trip to Mexico City with Canisius, I visited the heart of the cityâthe ZÃ³calo, which is the modern-day name for the main square. The experience was incredible, especially learning how this bustling plaza sits atop the ruins of the ancient city of Tenochtitlan, the capital of the Aztec Empire. This space, which today is surrounded by the grandeur of colonial-era architecture and governmental buildings, once housed the very center of the Aztec world. Itâs a living testament to Mexicoâs layered history.

As I stood in the square, I couldnât help but feel the weight of what was beneath my feet. Tenochtitlan, which was founded in 1325, was one of the largest cities in the world at its height, sitting on an island in the middle of Lake Texcoco. The Aztecs engineered a sophisticated city with floating gardens (chinampas) and canals that rivaled those of Venice. The location of the ZÃ³calo itself was the site of Templo Mayor, a grand temple dedicated to the gods Huitzilopochtli and Tlaloc. Although the Spaniards destroyed much of it during their conquest in 1521, you can still see remnants of the temple through archaeological excavations, which are visible right off the square.

The energy of the ZÃ³calo is palpableâwhether itâs the musicians playing traditional tunes, the street vendors selling indigenous crafts, or the vibrant political protests that sometimes fill the space. Itâs one of those places where the past and present seem to coexist so naturally. The knowledge that Tenochtitlan was a thriving metropolis, built with precision and spiritual significance, made me appreciate the enduring influence of Aztec culture on modern-day Mexico.

Walking through the nearby Museo del Templo Mayor and seeing artifacts, such as stone carvings, sculptures, and sacrificial altars, brought this history to life even more. I remember staring at a giant stone disc depicting Coyolxauhqui, the goddess dismembered by her brother Huitzilopochtli, in awe of how the Aztecs used art to tell their powerful myths.

Visiting the ZÃ³calo and understanding that it sits on the bones of Tenochtitlan, I realized how much of history can remain hidden beneath the surfaceâboth literally and figuratively. It was a profound experience that made me rethink how I view urban spaces, as every stone and structure seemed to have a story waiting to be uncovered. Itâs a reminder that cities are built on the legacies of civilizations past, and the ZÃ³calo is one of the best places to see those layers right in front of you.

text:
I spent 4 days at this property in July to celebrate my 62nd birthday and enjoy CDMX.  The property, staff, amenities, food, and location are excellent.  The 24/7 Central Cafe was especially convenient and the food tasty.

I would like to acknowledge the customer-centered culture I saw in each and every hotel employee that I interacted with.  From the housekeeper to the General Manager.  Everyone was friendly, professional, and happy to work at the hotel.

The staff definitely made this trip and birthday a memorable experience.  I would like to especially acknowledge our bellboy, Raul, who greeted us upon checking in, the concierge, Leyka, for her friendliness and assistance that she provided us.  A special thank you goes to Eric, the manager-in-charge who upgraded my room due to an issue with my initial room.  The General Manager, Nancy Gutierrez, went above and beyond in providing her personal touch to my visit.

I highly recommend the hotel and excellent staff to friends, family, and anyone looking for a hotel centrally located adjacent to the Zocalo.
dominant_topics_words: nice, great, amazing, place, food

text: Hanging room

The hotel was beautifully appointed. Every morning we were treated to a delicious breakfast at the roof top terrace overlooking the metropolitan cathedral and the national palace. In the evening we could enjoy courtesy drinks and snacks The staff were always attentive and accommodating. The room was small but very clean and comfortable. Cold bottled water and fresh apples were available to guests 24/7, also free of charge. The location was close to many historic sites and walking distance to the Palacio de Bellas artes, the meeting point for a lot of guided tours. The location
was not as clean or modern as Reforma and definitely more crowded but I enjoyed the central location to many attractions, shopping, and restaurants.

text:
Group of 5, booked a set of three rooms twice in July 2025.

Positives:
Great location and views in the central square / Zocalo.
Good service -- 24/7 snack bar, good breakfast included.
Spacious rooms and good beds / linens.

Negatives:
Could not sleep, there was music outside the hotel through the night (until after 5 AM). You can say that comes with the location, but not being able to sleep is a negative nevertheless.
WiFi is spotty, cannot rely on it for work calls. The signal was great but at times there was no internet access.
A/C thermostats don't seem to have effect, if you turn A/C on it just keeps cooling, so at night you have the choice of too hot or too warm.

text: We were delighted with our 17 -night stay last April at this elegant hotel in the historic centre of Mexico City. The staff were kind, friendly, and especially  helpful to us as non-Spanish speaking pensioners. Our room was comfortable, spotless, well-maintained and with coffee-making facilities.|Wide-ranging breakfast options included a varied buffet as well as dishes cooked to order such as enchiladas, which you can enjoy in a delightful balcony restaurant overlooking Latin America's biggest and grandest cathedral. You can have a four-course dinner here too, with multiple Mexican and international dishes on offer, and a spectacular view from the balcony by moonlight.. In addition, an attractive garden cafe bar, reached from above by a pleasing see-through lift, serves free food and drink to guests all day. Anyone staying in Mexico City could do no better than be guests of Zocalo Central Hotel.

text:
FOREIGNERS BE CAREFUL!!!

We initially made a reservation through Booking.com, and it was a pre-established price (US$944.08). We even thought the amount had been charged to our card. However, I was surprised when I arrived at the hotel and was told that the reservation was only a pre-reservation and that I would have to pay the fees in the hotel lobby. The hotel attendant's attitude was extremely rude and impatient, as if we were the ones in the wrong. Not to mention that the "pre-reservation" price was not applied, and we paid a much higher amount than the amount stated at the time of booking. Since this initial attitude didn't seem like a mistake, but rather a dynamic, we checked the room rates on the day we checked in. The same room for the same number of days was US$835.00, while we had to pay US$1,558.07. We were extremely upset after the incident, but since there was no time to look for another place, we agreed to stay. In any case, the least a real hotel could do is refund the overcharged amount as quickly as possible.

My wife and I stayed for six nights in May at the Zocalo Central Rooftop Mexico City.  It was one of the nicest hotel stays we have had in years. The location of the hotel is very central, the beautiful Constitution Square is across the street. The hotel is very nicely designed, very clean and very well maintained. There are many amenities, a cool towel and a shot of tequila when you arrive, a bar / cafe where you can find a wide variety of snacks and drinks that are available for free 24/7 (you do pay for alcohol).Â° The rooms are very well appointed with comfortable beds and monogrammed towels. There is a beautiful restaurant on the rooftop that overlooks Constitution Square where you can have the complimentary breakfast the hotel offers. The breakfast menu was extensive, fresh, very well prepared and beautifully presented. The restaurant is also open for dinner.  But what I think my wife and I appreciated the most about the Zocalo was the staff.  Everyone was so professional and so nice to us.  Mexico City was beautiful and we saw some amazing sites, wonderful restaurants and beautiful museums, but the Zocalo was our oasis. We didnât want to leave. Thanks to all the staff for helping to make our stay in Mexico City such a pleasant experience.

text:
Chapultepec Castle is located in the first section of Chapultepec Forest in Mexico City.
Its Baroque and Neoclassical design dates back to the Viceroyalty of New Spain, when the viceroys used to frequent Chapultepec to stroll and rest.
In 1840, the Heroic Military College established its headquarters in the castle. It also played a significant role in the Battle of Chapultepec as part of the American intervention in Mexico.
During the imperial transition, Maximilian of Habsburg and Charlotte lived in this castle, captivated by the beautiful views of the Valley of Mexico.
The castle also served as the presidential residence for most of the Mexican Revolution and until 1938.
A decree was issued requesting that the castle be used as the headquarters of the National Museum of History, and it opened its doors to the public for the first time on September 27, 1944.
Chapultepec Castle is the only castle in Latin America to have served as the official residence of a monarch.
It is open Tuesday through Sunday from 9:00 a.m. to 5:00 p.m.
General admission is 100 pesos and is free for children under 13, adults over 60, people with disabilities, and students and teachers with a valid ID.
If you travel to Mexico, be sure to visit the beautiful Chapultepec Castle. Its gardens and panoramic views are a must-see in the city.

text:
A cathedral, which is incredibly beautiful, with imposing architecture both inside and outside, along with the National Palace of Mexico City, are some of the most visible and beautiful spots surrounding Constitution Square and Mexico City in general.
The Cathedral's many years of history are extremely rich, having been founded by order of King Philip II and under construction from 1573 to 1813. Inside, aside from being able to pray and engage in other religious activities, you can walk aisle by aisle, admiring the Cathedral's immense and precious interior architecture, along with some important historical pieces from the church itself. At every step, you feel an aura of majesty and grandeur, conveyed by the Cathedral's perfectly polished construction.
It is an iconic landmark of the capital, and also a must-see, which you will definitely see if you pass through this area. A total wonder and deservedly declared a UNESCO World Heritage Site, it is enchanting.

text:
The Metropolitan Cathedral of Mexico City has been a World Heritage Site since 1987.
It is simply a beauty. Founded in 1570, the first stone was laid in 1571. Its construction took approximately 250 years, and it was inaugurated in 1813. It stands 67 meters high and covers an area of 7,752 mÂ².
It is designed in Gothic, Plateresque, Baroque, Estipite, and Neoclassical styles.
It is a monument that dominates the ZÃ³calo of Mexico City and is a must-see. The main altar, the Altar of the Kings, the Altar of Forgiveness, the naves and altars of the apse, the 14 chapels, the sacristy, the chapter house, the crypts, the remaining organs, the choir stalls, and the pendulum are all worth seeing and admiring for their beauty.
You can also climb the cathedral towers with a guide and admire the bell towers.
Admission is free, but climbing the bell towers and roofs costs 250 pesos per person.

text: The ZÃ³calo-TenochtitlÃ¡n station is the connection with our ancestors. It allows us to identify what our ancient civilization was like, with those models and drawings that represent our historical past. Walking through its wide corridors resembles the corridors that the ancient inhabitants of this region walked through. Seeing their images or their representations in those three-dimensional shapes makes us understand the magnitude, strength, and intelligence that went into constructing those buildings and temples, as well as their worship of their gods. It also helps us understand their way of thinking and their messages engraved in paintings and reliefs. I particularly enjoy walking in this area full of stories from our ancient colonizers. Thank you.

I either received no response at all, or they blatantly lied to me, saying it was just a deposit and that my bank would release it. text:
Beautiful spot downtown in Mexico City.
Colonial buildings surrounding Plaza de la ConstituciÃ³n are beautiful and well maintained. Also the Cathedral is just amazing in size. It's bells sound fill out the whole ZÃ²calo.
At Plaza de la constituciÃ³n, they install itinerant exhibitions, and decorations. So for sightseeing and walks this is great place to visit.
Also, there are several, museums, historical buildings, shops and  restaurants (all categories and prices) at a walking distance.

The central part, just down there at ZÃ³calo and some other streets are just for pedestrians. So one can have very nice walking time there (early in the morning perhaps the best time as it is not to crowded)

It is easy to get there by subway. Other public transportations and taxes are available. But subway would be the best idea... as parking are expensive and not that happy experience if you decide to go there driving.

text:
Admission is FREE only on Sundays, but be prepared as it can get very crowded. I recommend arriving early due to the sun and heat. Food and drinks are not allowed inside. Bring sunscreen or an umbrella. It's a walk of at least an hour, or more depending on the number of people. The walk up to the castle from the park is at least a 10-minute walk. Wear comfortable clothing; the descent is easier.

I don't recommend bringing strollers or wheelchairs, as mobility isn't yet adapted.

- Bring a healthy lunch. Outside, they sell various snacks, chips, and food, but the prices are excessive, and I don't think the quality is the best.

- It's best to go inside the restrooms; there are long lines outside the castle, and you'll have to wait a long time.

- You're located near the lake and Reforma Avenue.

Wow!  What an amazing experience overall.  From the beautiful decor, to the amazing staff, most notably the extremely helpful concierge Vianney and Patricia, Kenai (front desk) and Raul (door attendant) who went above and beyond to ensure we had the most pleasant stay.

text:
We visited this restaurant on a Friday night, catching the tail end of their busy hour. The host greeted us and mentioned a 20-minute wait, jotting our name and number on a piece of paper. Interestingly, other guests and reservations appeared to be managed through a tablet system, so it felt a bit disorganized from the start.

We waited outside and noticed several larger parties being seated ahead of us. Assuming they had reservations, we waited patiently. However, after a while, we decided to check inâonly to realize that the hostess had clearly forgotten us. She seated us shortly after.

Our server was polite but seemed to lack proper training. She took our appetizer and drink orders together, then returned with drinks and took our dinner order. We received our entrÃ©es, but had to remind her about the appetizers, which arrived late. One of the meals came out incorrectly, but to her credit, she did correct it fairly quickly.

When it came time to pay, confusion set in. We had clipped our cards to the respective tabs, but the charges appeared to be mixed up. To avoid further complications, we covered the difference between ourselves. Later, we discovered that one card was charged twice, instead of charging the two separate cards provided.

As for the foodâit was underwhelming.

Overall, the experience was more frustrating than enjoyable.
dominant_topics_words: nice, great, amazing, place, food

text:
Came here with a group of 7 and overallâ¦ it was underwhelming. Our server was decent at first, but once he realized the tip was automatically included, we barely saw him again; meanwhile, the smaller tables got the real attention. My plate honestly felt a little sad because the chicken was dry and lacked flavor. Also, for a brunch spot, not offering coffee is just wild to me.

The atmosphere and aesthetic were actually really nice, the space is bright and well put together, and the swings are a fun touch that definitely add to the vibe. But that only goes so far.

A $16+ breakfast burrito feels like a stretch. I know prices are up, but breakfast should be more accessible, not a luxury. Drinks were okay. I also tried the lobster quesadilla, and while it sounded fancy, it barely had any lobster despite the price.

All in all, great setting, but the food and service didnât live up to it. Not in a rush to come back.

text: Awesome to visit!!

You can read the other reviews for the church itself. This one will focus on the catacomb / crypt (the guide called it a crypt) experience, since there's not much info about it online.

In essence, the catacomb / crypt tour is only on Fridays from 11am to ~4pm. I forget how much admission was, but it was pretty cheap (~$5 USD). You can only buy tickets in person from a guide posted in front of the middle chamber of the church; cash only.

The tour is ONLY in Spanish. You will see one or two side chambers of the church, then the middle chamber with the giant organs (some or the largest in North America), then descend steps from there down to the crypts. No photography is allowed except in the crypt where the former Archbishops were buried. Total tour time is ~1 hour.

text: To pass the time

The Hotel ZÃ³calo Central is an excellent hotel with an incredible location and superb amenities. The beds are very comfortable and the restaurant with breakfast, lunch and dinner has some of the best views of the ZÃ³calo by far.  The prices are very reasonable given the fact that there is a cafe with complimentary food and beverage options all day long. And, the food and coffee is delicious. Free bottles of water are in fridges on every floor. The breakfast is excellent and the staff are all very friendly. There is a small gym, but you can also access Alameda park and the square very easily if you like to jog or run. My husband and I have stayed a few times, and it is always delightful. They even gave us an anniversary gift of two adorable stuffed penguins. My only negative comment would be that the wifi can be spotty and slow and our TV was not working properly , but these were minor details.

text: We loved visiting the castle.  It has a lot of interesting artifacts, paintings and excellent views of the city and the angel.  The architecture of the castle is amazing.  I appreciate that there is an elevator, since we have a handicap person with us.  I must warn you that the hike up to the castle is quite long and I saw a few people nearly passing out.  But I think that if you are moderately active, the hike might be difficult but not impossible.  Beware of the food vendors in the food section. We ordered chicken and broth and were charged 90 pesos, for a very small bowl.  That was 20 pesos more than what I paid for a huarache with sudadero, which was larger and with more meat.  This was at the section with the blue umbrellas.  Our server forgot our order, when he finally brought it it was incomplete.  The chicken broth was not on the menu, so we didn't know the price.  It was my mistake for not asking the price before hand.  When I question him about the excessive cost, he said it was because it must of had a lot of chicken.  With prices in Mexico they would have to use half a chicken to justify the price.  Other than that insident, our trip was great.  You need the whole day to be able to explore more of Chapultepec.  A must see when in Mexico city.

text:
I was struggling to give 4 or 5 but after thinking about the housekeeping I give a 4

As mentioned the housekeeping is a disappointment. We left the room every morning and back around 4 with the clean room sign hanging at the door. The room was not cleaned and untouched. We had to ask them to come and clean them again around 5. I understand that was the busiest time of the year but not cleaning your room for such a long time. Guests just want a clean room to rest after a long day out

The gym is very small as people mentioned. The absurd thing is you cannot go to the gym on the first floor with your key card. You need to go to the reception and ask them to get you to the 1/f

The hotel is stylish and I like it
We also like the concept they give free drinks but the coffee is bad. It is coffee water not coffee .. I donât know how

The location is a plus and minus. The plus side is you can easily access to the busiest area of the city and zocalo for sights and experience

The minus was since it was around Christmas time most of the time cars cannot get close to the hotel. The first time we came by taxi it took us triple the time and the taxi could not get into the hotel with all roads blocked
For the next coming days we could not get taxi right at the the hotel or dropping off at the spot
You simply need to walk 5 mins away from the busiest area to get the transportation

Other than these problems I would recommend to stay there but not during Christmas or festival times

The tacos were stuffed to the brim and very filling. The quesabirria taco came with consummÃ© for dipping and it was perfect.  Three of them filled me up and I took the last one to go. It was still delicious the next day! The atmosphere is bright and beautiful, the bathrooms were clean and easy to find, and there are bar seats with swings if you like that kind of thing. Bonus: The horchata was super cinnamony and delicious!

text: I am going to be one of the few people that does not give this a 5 star, not that its a bad thing just my opinion.    This is more of an upscale place with high end food choices and pricey drinks.  For two, we had the 4 course option, 3 drinks and glass of wine, was about 250.00 dollars.  To put that in perspective the day before for a group of 8, I spent about the same amount at cafe Tacuba.  That being said the atmosphere is great you will feel and know you are in a high end place, the minute you step off the elevator.   There will be no confusion, that you will be paying more for your meal than some Mexicans makes in almost a month (I Googled that info). As for the service it was on point. After each meal, my fork was replaced with a clean fork.  Also the views, at night from the balcony facing the Cathedral are amazing.  As for the food it was good, but I personally cannot justify the price to the portions.  If you are a regular sized guy you will, leave hungry I am 6,2 at 250 and was ready to go get me some street tacos afterward.  But of course for the ladies they were perfect portion size.  The food is good, I would not say great, and it is very much so, fancy Mexican food, or foo foo food.  Hopefully this will help you to decide if this is for you or not.

We ordered the chefs choice menu with a group of 8. The lentil soup was cold and tasted unfortunately like boiled water with lentil and a few pieces of pork belly. No flavor. The bruschetta was not good. Bread was very hard and tasted stale. The white fish and the steak were great. Desserts were good. Got charged for an extra water of Perrier and got charged for a more expensive drink than the one I ordered. They did mess up two items but handled the situation very well. Quite frankly for the price, I would not recommend this place unless you value view over food and value. I also had a similar average experience last year where one of the main dishes was horribly over salted.

The service was always good but understaffed with servers so getting their attention is hard - not their fault. They were so polite just not enough of them.

text:
Zocalo was recommended, and it did not disappoint. Their menu is creative and has some great twists on Mexican cuisine.

Started with the Chips & Salsa. Fresh crispy chips fresh out the fryer and very tasty salsa with a good kick. I tried several of their tacos and they were all great. Tacos I tried: Panela Mushroom, Steak Chimichurri, El Macho, Quesabirria, and Eaquites. To wet my taste buds, I had the Ancho Old Fashion. And it was delicious.

Abigail, our server, was great. Friendly and very attentive. Constantly checked in on us. Followed her suggestions, and they were great.

I recommend Zocalo to everyone.

text:
Update 5 months later : Completely unprofessional and inappropriate sanitary standards.

Staff is serving while munching on their snacks. It's super unsanitary. And who wants a server talking to you while they're still chewing their food? Or putting the lime in their Corona, when they haven't washed their hands and just munched on chips and salsa.

The staff seemed largely distracted by consuming their own snacks/ meals any chance they got. Even my date questioned from the moment we walked in, "why is the staff eating/ chewing" he thought they were having a staff party or get together.

The chicken quesadilla we had (and had previously on a separate visit) was not as good as the previous time and served with no salsas. The Chili Rellanos were mediocre.

The entire visit was such a turn off due to the staff eating and not washing their hands.

We did speak to the manager and I expressed my concerns and even emailed the owners. This is unacceptable.

I don't recommend.

text:
I finally met the cook called Sergio and what a pleasure it was! He's a master at his craft, yet so humble and down to earth. Abigail took care of service today and at least once before and she's so attentive and professional. I don't remember who all I've had for servers before except for Angelo, an excellent bartender, but  every single time I come in, I'm absolutely impressed by every detail of my experience. My first visit was no more than a couple of months ago and I've visited probably 10 times since. I waited until today to write a review because I was looking for some reason to temper all this praise with at least one thing I found them lacking in, because nothing is perfect.... But Zocalo is reliably perfect. So shout out to manager Ashley, because though we haven't met, you're obviously doing things right.

I've tried several of the street tacos here and I love them all, but el pastor is #1. I've searched high and low for pastor in the Springs only to be disappointed. Zocalo is so far above the rest, it's ridiculous.

By the way, their happy hour deals are crazy, I feel like I'm stealing from them. The atmosphere is incredible, the decor is beautiful, and I'm a patron for life!

text:
The Metropolitan Cathedral in Mexico City is a must-see historical gem for any traveler. Its majestic Baroque faÃ§ade, topped by twin towers, announces an interior of sublime beauty. Upon entering, visitors are amazed by the grandeur of the nave, the gilded altarpieces, and the side chapels decorated with sacred art from the 16th to 18th centuries. History also resonates here: it has been the religious heart of the city since its founding. Its location in the ZÃ³calo, next to emblematic buildings, facilitates a complete cultural tour, combining architecture, faith, and heritage. Visiting it offers an authentic and profound experience of Mexico City.
A place of enormous energy, it overwhelms you as soon as you enter. A truly beautiful and intense experience.

Visiting Chapultepec Castle was a truly enjoyable experience. The entrance process was smooth and well-organized, making it easy to get in without long waits or confusion. Once inside, the beauty of the castle really stood out â from the elegant staircases to the detailed paintings and historic accessories that decorate the rooms.

What made the visit even more pleasant was that it wasnât overly crowded, allowing for a relaxed and unhurried exploration of the space. One of the highlights was stepping out onto the terraces â the panoramic views of Mexico City from up there are absolutely breathtaking and not to be missed.

Overall, Chapultepec Castle offers a great mix of history, art, and scenic views. A must-visit for anyone spending time in Mexico City.

text: With the best company ever, friends who are my family

Going up to the ZÃ³calo Balcony is, from the outset, a promise: the city at your feet, the sunset gilding the Cathedral, and a chef's menu that, at least on paper, promises a sensory experience worthy of the highest standards.

And in the kitchen, it delivered.
The Lentil Soup was a warm, profound start, with flavors that seemed to come from a kitchen steeped in history. The beef fillet sope, small but powerful, struck a perfect balance between traditional and refined. The Totoaba Loinâsimply sublimeâcooked to the point of perfection. And the chocolate cheesecake, elegant without being pretentious, rounded out with a wine pairing that complemented it without stealing the show. It was, without exaggeration, a first-class execution. Cuisine that walks firmly down the runway of the memorable.

But then, the service.
There, the narrative changed. Long silences. Gazes searching for someone who hadn't come. Dishes that never arrived, but were still charged for. A service pace so rushed that you doubted whether you were dining or racing against the clock. And the final irony: after the last bite, we were asked to leave a review.

So here it is:
A cuisine with vision and technique, the kind you'd recommend without a second thought. But marred by service that seemed improvised, as if a museum painting had been hung with thumbtacks.

In a place where the cuisine is top-notch, the service can't afford to be grounded. Because when you dine at the BalcÃ³n del ZÃ³calo, you don't just expect a meal. You expect an experience. And this time, the scales were off.

The Metropolitan Cathedral is a true architectural masterpiece, the scale, symmetry, and craftsmanship are awe-inspiring. From the moment you step inside, you're surrounded by intricate stonework, soaring ceilings, and an overwhelming sense of history and reverence.

The interior is equally stunning, with beautifully preserved artwork, ornate altars, and the magnificent organ pipes that dominate the space. It's not just a religious site  itâs a cultural and artistic treasure that tells centuries of stories through its details.

Whether you're there for quiet reflection, admiration of the craftsmanship, or historical interest, itâs easily a  must-see when visiting Mexico City.

text:
Mexico City Metropolitan Cathedral: Jewel of the Capital's ZÃ³calo
The Metropolitan Cathedral of the Assumption of the Blessed Virgin Mary into Heaven in Mexico City stands as one of the most emblematic and majestic monuments in Latin America, dominating the north side of the ZÃ³calo or Plaza de la ConstituciÃ³n in the heart of Mexico City's Historic Center.
History and Construction
The history of this monumental cathedral dates back to the colonial period. After the conquest of Mexico-TenochtitlÃ¡n, HernÃ¡n CortÃ©s ordered the construction of a first major church in 1524, built with stones from destroyed indigenous temples and strategically located where the four causeways leading to the Aztec spiritual center converged. However, this initial construction soon proved insufficient for the spiritual needs of the viceroyalty's capital. Construction of the current cathedral formally began in 1573, under the direction of the Spanish architect Claudio de Arciniega, who was inspired by the cathedrals of JaÃ©n and Valladolid. The project represented a titanic undertaking that spanned 240 years, concluding in 1813 under the direction of architect Manuel TolsÃ¡.
Architectural Features
The cathedral is an extraordinary compendium of architectural styles that reflects the different periods of its construction. Its main faÃ§ade displays the Renaissance, Baroque, and Neoclassical styles that developed during the Viceroyalty. The dimensions of the temple are impressive: 61 meters wide by 128 meters long and 67 meters high to the top of the towers.
The interior consists of five naves with a transept, with 51 vaults, 74 arches, and 40 columns. The structure includes fourteen side chapels, each with its own character and artistic treasures. The floor is made of Tepeaca marble, and its walls and vaults are made of stone.
Artistic Treasures
Among the most notable artistic treasures is the Altar of the Kings, considered one of the masterpieces of Churrigueresque Baroque in the Americas. This magnificent work was created by JerÃ³nimo de BalbÃ¡s between 1718 and 1725, and gilded by Francisco MartÃ­nez in 1736. The altarpiece measures 25 meters high, 13 meters wide, and 7 meters deep, and is made of carved white cedar wood covered with gold leaf. The Altar of Forgiveness, also by JerÃ³nimo de BalbÃ¡s, is located in the central nave along with the Cathedral Choir, which features two magnificent organs. The paintings decorating the Altar of the Kings are by the prominent artist Juan RodrÃ­guez JuÃ¡rez, including "The Assumption of the Virgin Mary" and "The Adoration of the Magi."
The ZÃ³calo: Historical Context
The cathedral is located in Constitution Square, popularly known as the ZÃ³calo, which, at 46,800 square meters, is the second largest square in the world after Tiananmen Square. This square was named in honor of the CÃ¡diz Constitution promulgated in 1812. The term "ZÃ³calo" comes from the base built during the government of Antonio LÃ³pez de Santa Anna to erect a commemorative column of independence. The foundation was never completed, but its base remained in place for several years. Since pre-Hispanic times, this space has been the spiritual, political, and cultural center of Mexico, serving as the setting for important historical events.
World Heritage Site
The Metropolitan Cathedral, along with the Historic Center of Mexico City, was declared a World Heritage Site by UNESCO in 1987. This recognition is due to its exceptional architectural value and historical significance as a testament to the fusion of Indigenous and Spanish cultures.

text: Sergio is the owner and he serves food, talks to patrons and I can see how much his staff admire him. Everyone was happy. The staff all have good vibes and with Sergio leading, I can see he sets the tone. The food is so fresh and seasoned so perfectly. Sergio said that his recipes come from old Mexico City, very traditional. The margaritas are so delicious and they use fresh juices, no store bought mix. I had the Classico with Mezcal, instead of tequila. It comes with a sun-dried lime and has perfect balance. Not too sweet, not bitter, not too acidic, and a perfect amount of liquor. I love the refried beans-smooth, seasoned so well and a little touch of imported Mexican cheese that is nutty, and actually has flavor, as opposed to the normal bland cheese that many other restaurants serve. The Mexican rice has a hint of saffron with rich tomatoes. I usually donât eat the rice but this rice is irresistible. I had the fajitas, the combo of steak and shrooms. The steak is smokey, with a tangy mouth-watering dose of lime. The shrooms are meaty and would make a great vegan or vegetarian meal. It comes with red peppers and onions that still have a bit of crunch. The chips are perfectly cooked, crisp and seasoned. They come in a brown paper bag and if your lucky, they may be right out of the fryer. The ambiance is fun and they have swings to sit on. The kids will love this and so do the adults. The music is also great. Sergio wanted me to try the birria taco and gave me one for free. So damn good. He also gave me some tamales to take home. He told me he likes to keep his prices reasonable and they are. Do yourself a favor, and eat there. I promise, you will leave happy. I canât remember any restaurant owner giving free food, sitting at your table to talk about where you are from and expressing gratitude for dining at their establishment. Times have changed, but at Zocalo, you feel valued and to me, that means so much.

text:
The menu includes a four-course meal, which includes an appetizer, a corn-based snack, the main course, and dessert. There are three options for each course, and you can combine them, which I think is an excellent idea.

The price of the menu depends on the choice of main course, ranging from approximately 850 to 1,300. It's worth noting that drinks are separate.

The dishes are beautifully presented and the portions adequate. Although the appetizer and snack are small, the main course is enough to satisfy.

The view of downtown Mexico City, which allows you to see the ZÃ³calo, and therefore the National Palace and the Mexico City government building, as well as the cathedral, is worth it.

text:
BalcÃ³n del ZÃ³calo is a contemporary Mexican restaurant.
We arrived shortly after breakfast; their lunch service starts at 1 p.m. Their menu includes sharing dishes priced from $600 to $800.
But since we were hungry, we decided to choose the four-course menu, priced per person from $890 to $1,200, depending on the main course.
We tried clam ceviche, tortilla soup, tacos, and the exquisite fish loin and steak.
If you're a wine lover, they offer wines by the glass starting at $250 or $1,200 by the bottle.
The view of the cathedral is perfect from tables near the railing.
We also liked the cocktails (gins).
Definitely a place to enjoy in every way.
We hope to return soon to try their breakfast buffet.

text:
Some positives:

The happy hour pricing is great, so sometimes we go for happy hour. The $3 tacos are very, very generously-sized for the price, and the chips+salsa are good. I often order grilled fish tacos, which are generally tasty and very filling. For non-HH dining, there are lots of options for carnivores to vegans and most things are intrinsically gluten free. It's nice to have a menu that is geared slightly more toward southern Mexico. The margaritas are done well and the beer selection is appropriate to the venue.

However, there are some pretty consistent issues:

The place smells intensely of the fryer. If you wear a jacket in, it will still smell awful a few days later. Not subtly either; the people around you will notice how awful you smell. This has been the case since they opened, and it's the primary reason we take breaks from Zocalo.

Certain food items are a little rough. The fried fish is grey and slimy and unpleasant to eat. The carne asada is grey and bland. Food items have come out with small mistakes regularly, such as missing salsa or a taco that was never garnished at all.

The beer is sometimes flat. I think there's a bit of a line pressure issue that a distributor could solve.

The range in quality of service is from awful to pretty good, with no clear indication of why it's sometimes so bad. We're often ignored for too long/indefinitely, or the order is taken wrong, or there's an issue with the check (or the gratuity entered at the end of the shift). Sometimes they are understaffed but we've noticed the same problems when they are heavily staffed.

Overall, the issues aren't enough to totally take away our desire to eat there occasionally, especially given happy hour pricing, but solving those issues would greatly enhance the experience.
dominant_topics_words: good, beautiful, place, eat, service, food, service, bad, tacos, order

text:
The service at this restaurant was one of the worst Iâve experienced in a long time. The fact that it took 10 minutes for the waitress to bring chips and salsa shouldâve been a warning for what was to come. We had chips and salsa that sat empty for 20 minutes. We also had our water bottle empty for well over 20 mins needing a refill. We looked all over for her to ask for a refill but did not see her for a while. Eventually she passed us after giving another table chips and salsa and still did not refill our chips or water. We continued to wait 30-40 minutes for our food, which for 2 people, is pretty excessive, weâre assuming she forgot to put in our order. Over that span of time we saw her maybe 2 times. She eventually came over when we flagged her down and she asked to refill the salsa. She came back with only the salsa and forgot the chips. She came back and said the chips were out and they were refrying them. When our food came finally came out she forgot both of our tacos and had to go back and get them. Then about 20 mins later after promising chips, she returned, but we were already finishing up. We waited another 15 minutes waiting for our check which never came so we had to go to the bar and ask them to get our waitress.

Overall, terrible service. Waitress will ignore and neglect you. The food isnât bad but for the service and time it takes to receive your food, youâre better off eating elsewhere. Iâd only recommend if youâre in a pinch for places open, not if youâre in a pinch for time. This would be the worst place to go if youâre in a pinch for time.

text:
BalcÃ³n del ZÃ³calo offers an exceptional dining experience primarily defined by its unrivaled views of Mexico City's historic ZÃ³calo, including the Metropolitan Cathedral and National Palace. Securing a balcony table, provides a truly spectacular backdrop.

The cuisine is modern Mexican, characterized by creative interpretations of traditional dishes and a strong emphasis on high-quality ingredients. Plates are elegantly presented, reflecting a fine-dining approach without being overly formal.
Service is consistently attentive and professional. The combination of the iconic location, refined cuisine, and polished service justifies the cost for a memorable occasion.

text: Iâm new to town and was looking for a Mexican food place with good chow and fun ambiance for a Saturday night. Look no further mi amigos! This place is swingin (pun intended - the bar swing seats are great for the kids). The horchata is so creamy and the sprinkled cinnamon adds a nice touch. Little weird to see a charge for chips and salsa, but after having them Iâd gladly try again (next time with guac!) - they were crispy, lightly oiled, and salty. Kids had the enchiladas - they went with server Katieâs recommendation of beef with red sauce and chicken with green. These meals come with rice and beans, but tacos do not. My wife and I had the tacos, which did not disappoint - the carne asada is bigger than normal but is delicious. I also tried the quesabirria and shrimp, also good (although the shrimp was breaded and I prefer grilled). The highlight of the night was when I asked for spicier salsa. Katie went back and asked Sergio if they had any and he just whipped me up a phenomenal chili diarbo, Serrano, habenero salsa. He came out to check on us and insisted we try the salsa in the el macho - pretty fantastic as well! Overall everything we were looking for a weekend out - definitely a place Iâll be bringing family back to!

text: Wonderful!!

The Historic Center of Mexico City is a fascinating place that encapsulates centuries of history, culture and architecture. Walking through its streets is like taking a trip back in time, where each corner reveals a part of the rich heritage of the Mexican capital.

One of the main attractions is the ZÃ³calo, one of the largest squares in the world, surrounded by impressive buildings such as the Metropolitan Cathedral and the National Palace, which houses the famous murals by Diego Rivera. These sites offer an in-depth look at the history and art of Mexico.

The Templo Mayor, located just steps from the ZÃ³calo, is another highlight. The Aztec ruins and adjacent museum allow visitors to explore the city's pre-Hispanic past. As one ventures deeper into the Historic Center, one finds streets full of life, vibrant markets, and a variety of shops and restaurants offering everything from traditional crafts to delicious Mexican food.

The Historic Center is also home to important museums, such as the Museo del Palacio de Bellas Artes, known for its impressive Art Nouveau architecture and interior murals, and the Casa de los Azulejos, with its facade covered in Talavera tiles. The mix of colonial, modern and pre-Hispanic buildings creates a unique and charming urban landscape.

Visiting the Historic Center of Mexico City is an enriching experience that offers something for everyone: history, culture, art, gastronomy and vibrant urban life. It is a place where the past and present coexist harmoniously, inviting visitors to explore and discover the essence of Mexico City.

text: Quite expensive

We had an incredible experience at BalcÃ³n.

Hereâs what we loved:
- Phenomenal service: due to the teacher protest we were late for our reservation but they waited patiently for us to arrive; waitstaff was always helpful, quick to refill water/drinks and never skipped a beat with our questions about the menu.
- drinks were unique and exceptionally tasty
- views of Plaza de ConstitutiÃ³n and the buildings were incredible.
- food was top notch!  Our group chose to do the pick 3 option on the menu: Tirana ceviche, shrimp taco, filet taco, octopus, tlacoyo tacos, totoaba filet on mole, heirloom tomato salad, rib-eye, everything was absolutely delicious!
- perfect portion-size
- never felt rushed to finish an item
- heaters were flanking our table which helped as the temperature cooled outside.

Things I would change if we could:
- our choices of clothing! We were right at the front of the balcony which was fantastic for the amazing views but it was quite windy. I would have worn nice pants and brought a thicker sweater.
- prepare for a lot of traffic getting there especially if there is a protest going on (we had to walk the last few blocks due to road closures associated with the teachersâ protest).

text: We spent 4 days in Mexico City. Itâs a beautiful place, we had an incredible time and the service and food was outstanding at every turn. Except here! We booked a reservation weeks in advance, very excited to experience the cuisine and take in the incredible view from this restaurant. Upon our arrival in the city, we learned that there was a massive protest happening obstructing the view and making it difficult to travel to the area. As soon as we learned of this, we reached out to the restaurant. Because it was the same day they charged us $70 CAD. I asked if there was any way under the circumstances they could wave the charge. I was told that was not possible. I am very disappointed the restaurant did not notify us of the protest when they reached out to confirm the reservation the day prior and they werenât willing to do anything about the charge. Our trip was such a pleasure outside of this experience and itâs just too bad.

text: Mexico City's Historic Center is a must-see if you're visiting. It has recently been closed to vehicles, which makes the area's architectural beauty even more appreciated. You can get there by car; there are several parking lots in the surrounding area, and you can also easily take the metro by getting off at the Bellas Artes, Allende, or ZÃ³calo stations. Clothing stores, jewelry stores, opticians with very affordable prices, currency exchange centers, restaurants, museums, places to find books at good prices, the Torre Latinoamericana, and countless accessory storesâyou're sure to find whatever you're looking for. There are wheelchair-accessible spaces and establishments with public restrooms. Bellas Artes, the Alameda, the Museum of Memory and Tolerance, the National Museum of Art, etc.âa weekend is definitely not enough.

text:
I honestly expected more from the food. I know the portions are small to enhance the flavor. The bad thing was that they weren't.

Well, for the first course, it was a salad, you could say like a caprese salad with strawberries. The strawberries were half overcooked, the tomato ball was too hard for my taste, and the pesto was delicious. The presentation was amazing.
For the second course, a tlacoyo, to be honest, was unbelievable, delicious, I would go back just for that dish.
For the third course, I think it was a sea bass loin. It was supposed to be juicy, unfortunately, it came out dry, I think it was overcooked or overcooked in the pan.
For the last course, I don't quite remember what its name was, like a chocolate volcano cake, but it was rectangular. Honestly, it stung me. I don't know if it had too much cinnamon or another ingredient that I can't really identify.
I would go back, maybe, but in the future.

text:
DO NOT EAT HERE â They will steal from you and ignore you.

I had a very frustrating and disappointing experience at Balcon de Zocalo in Mexico City. While the food and views were beautiful, our visit was ultimately ruined by dishonesty and terrible customer service.

Last year, I went with a friend who attempted to pay with his Capital One card. The first card didnât work, so he tried a second one, which also didnât go through. When he went back to the first card, it finally worked. The staff assured us that the failed transactions were voided and would not be charged.

That turned out to be false. Both âvoidedâ transactions went through, and we were charged multiple times for one meal. Weâve been trying to get our money back since June of last year, and despite countless emails and calls, weâve gotten nothing but empty promises. We even had a Spanish-speaking friend from El Salvador call on our behalf, and they hung up on her. That kind of behavior strongly suggests a lack of honesty and integrity.

Weâve also reached out repeatedly on Instagram and Facebook for almost a yearâagain, no resolution. All weâve asked for is a simple receipt to prove to Capital One that the duplicate charges were fraudulent, and they refuse to provide even that.

It's deeply upsetting to be out hundreds of dollars after being told we wouldnât be charged. As tourists, we expected more from a place as prominent as Balcon de Zocalo. If you're an American or international visitor, avoid paying by card hereâyour money may not be safe.

What could have been a lovely experience turned into a nightmare. It's a shame that such a well-known establishment would operate in this way. Be warned

text: I'd been there before, but I didn't like it this time; I'll delete it from my list. As for the menu, you must have all three courses. The drinks were warm, the tequila was very expensive! The carajillo was cheesy. The atmosphere was awful; the music was lacking in style, and it was too hot. text: Ideal to admire the art of this construction!

I recently had the pleasure of staying at this hotel for a 3-night stay, and I must say it was an excellent experience from start to finish.

Firstly, the check-in process was smooth and efficient. The staff at the front desk were friendly, welcoming, and knowledgeable. They provided all the necessary information about the hotel amenities and made me feel valued as a guest.

The room itself was spacious, clean, and well-appointed. The bed was comfortable, ensuring a good night's sleep after a long day of exploring the city. The bathroom was also spotless and stocked with high-quality toiletries.

One of the highlights of my stay was the hotel's dining options. The breakfast buffet offered a wide variety of delicious options, from fresh fruits and pastries to hot cooked dishes. In addition, they offered a free menu at the restaurant (soups, salads, sadwiches, snacks, soft drinks, frozen drinks and beer) The restaurant staff were attentive and accommodating, making sure that all guests were well taken care of.

The hotel's location was also ideal for exploring the city. It was conveniently located near popular attractions and public transportation options, making it easy to get around. Additionally, the hotel provided helpful recommendations for nearby restaurants and activities.

Last but not least, the service at this hotel was top-notch. The staff went above and beyond to ensure that my stay was enjoyable and hassle-free. From housekeeping to the concierge, everyone was professional, friendly, and always ready to assist with any requests or inquiries.

Overall, my 3-night stay at this hotel was truly excellent. The combination of outstanding service, comfortable accommodations, delicious and free dining options, and convenient location made for an unforgettable experience. I highly recommend this hotel to anyone looking for a memorable stay in the area.
dominant_topics_words: nice, great, amazing, place, food

text: One of the best hotel services we've ever had. The location is wonderful, and the room is comfortable and well-suited to our needs. It's close to several interesting places within walking distance. Besides the rooftop restaurant, there are many restaurants nearby. They offer a free guided walking tour (Spanish/English), which we took and loved. Oh, and it's worth mentioning the 24-hour cafÃ© on the ground floor, open to guests, with breads, sandwiches, pastries, and a variety of delicious treats. We can't forget to mention the excellent service we received from everyone, but especially from concierges Michele and Salvador, who were incredibly helpful with our city tours, including money-saving and safety tips. text:
Hands Down Best Tacos In Colorado Springs

My wife and I have been going to Zocalo for the past 9 months and it has quickly become one of our favorite spots in the Springs.  We love the food and their drink menu is spectacular but I think the part we like most is the staff and owner.  Itâs rare, especially in todayâs day and age, to go to the same restaurant and see the same staff over a long period of time and I think the fact that we see the same familiar faces each time we go in speaks volumes to the atmosphere and the vibe going on there.  The staff and bartenders are friendly, attentive, and knowledgeable and the owner is so humble and easy going.

Going back to the food, my wife and I love street tacos and have been to just about every spot in the Springs and we both agree Zocalo is our favorite.  The El Macho and Quesabirria are my favorite and my wife, as a pescatarian, loves the fact that she has so many options there (her favorite is the Equites)â¦ and if youâre there on the weekend donât miss out on the Poke Nachos.  Their drink menu also has a lot of unique cocktails on it and we appreciate that all the drinks are made with real ingredients (no sour mix here).  The El Jefe and Mezcal Sour are great drinks but we find ourselves going back to the Mexican Blood and Sand more times than not.

I honestly canât say enough good things about this place, we initially went for the food and drink but find ourselves coming back over and over again for the vibe and the people.  Thereâs something special going on here and Iâm just happy to be a small part of it.
dominant_topics_words: good, beautiful, place, eat, service, nice, great, amazing, place, food, food, service, bad, tacos, order

text: Fun taco place in downtown COS.   No matter what your appetite, this place will have a well constructed, yummy taco for you.   From traditional carnitas, to sweet and spicy el pastor, to lengua and beef cheek these made to order tacos are top of the line delish. There are even seafood and veggies options available.   They also serve house made salsa (just the right balance of heat and heavy on the cilantro), queso, an sauces made to go with the tacos.  Fun place to head for a group gathering or needing to lift your spirits after a long grueling day.   During happy hour M-Thurs the tacos of the day are half priced just an FYI.

text:
A unique experience that blends history, culture, and urban life

I recently visited Mexico City's Historic Center, and the experience was much more than a sightseeing tour: it was a journey through time and the many identities that coexist here. From the moment you arrive, it's impossible not to feel the weight of history and the vibrant energy that surrounds it.

This is where you'll find some of the country's most iconic sites, such as the ZÃ³calo, the Metropolitan Cathedral, the National Palace, and the Templo Mayor. Everything is close by and easy to explore on foot. Every corner has something to tell: stunning architecture, street art, traditional sounds like organ grinders, and the comings and goings of people that keep everything moving.

What surprised me most was the mix of old and new. You can see colonial buildings alongside modern shops, interactive museums, galleries, restaurants, and charming cafes. I highly recommend visiting the Palacio de Bellas Artes (both inside and out) and the Casa de los Azulejos. There are also many museums for those who enjoy art and history, such as the MUNAL (Mexican Museum of Art and History) and the Templo Mayor Museum.

The food is also excellent. From street vendors selling tacos, tlacoyos, and ice creams to places serving more elaborate traditional Mexican food, there are options for all budgets.

Of course, as in any urban center, you should be careful with your belongings and avoid lonely streets at night. Security has improved significantly, and there is police presence in the busiest areas, but it's always a good idea to proceed with caution.
dominant_topics_words: good, beautiful, place, eat, service, nice, great, amazing, place, food, food, service, bad, tacos, order, service, fast, delicious, food, good

text: The only bad thing is having to run into the national guard inside the temple.
dominant_topics_words: good, beautiful, place, eat, service

text:
The Metropolitan Cathedral, a monumental presence in Mexico City's ZÃ³calo, is a breathtaking testament to centuries of architectural evolution and artistic devotion. Its faÃ§ade alone is a symphony of styles, a living chronicle etched in stone, spanning from the restrained austerity of its early Renaissance foundations to the exuberant flourish of its Baroque and Neoclassical embellishments. Twin bell towers pierce the sky, their intricate carvings and statuary reaching towards the heavens, while the central dome, a masterful feat of engineering, crowns the edifice with majestic grace.
Within, the grandeur continues. Soaring vaulted ceilings draw the eye upward, supported by massive columns that create a sense of profound scale. Sunlight, filtered through stained-glass windows, casts a kaleidoscope of colors across polished floors and gilded altarpieces, illuminating the rich tapestry of religious art. Every chapel, every corner, reveals meticulous craftsmanship: elaborate Churrigueresque retablos shimmering with gold leaf, delicate Rococo details whispering tales of devotion, and solemn Neoclassical forms exuding an air of dignified reverence. The sheer ambition, the fusion of diverse aesthetics, and the enduring quality of its construction make the Metropolitan Cathedral a truly awe-inspiring marvel of human ingenuity and spiritual expression.
dominant_topics_words: good, beautiful, place, eat, service, service, fast, delicious, food, good

text:
Perfect meal and experience! We came for a 7:15 reservation and was able to be sat a bit before, which was perfect to see the sunset. I had the tepache and my girlfriend had the pornstar martini. We shared the blanco loco. The tepache was perfect- not too sweet and the mezcal smoky flavor held strong. The pornstar martini was nice, the maracuya flavor was prominent, but we wished there was more vanilla flavor. The blanco loco is sweet but delicious and an interesting texture.

We shared the four course menu and chose: the oysters, the crab taco, the beef mole and the chocolate cake. We were not very hungry so it was the perfect amount for the both of us. The oysters had many different textures which was interesting, but a bit overwhelming on the palette. I believe it contained miso glaze, but could not taste the umami flavor. The crab taco was lovely. A nice blend of textures (crunchy fried crab, onions and aioli) and flavors (avocado, lime and sweet crab). The star of the show was definitely the beef. Perfectly cooked, it tasted like butter and a wonderful mole sauce. The chicharrÃ³n balls and asparagus/brussel sprouts made for some interesting texture and flavor combinations. The chocolate cake dessert was light, creamy and buttery. Our waiter, Fabian, was very attentive and gave us great recommendations. When hearing of my girlfriendâs dairy allergy, they made sure to give us salsa with our bread instead of butter so she could enjoy. Highly recommend for a memorable experience.
dominant_topics_words: nice, great, amazing, place, food

text:
Amazing ambiance, exceptional service, and breathtaking views. BalcÃ³n del ZÃ³calo is truly a gem! From the moment you step in, you can tell they take serious pride in every detail. The decor is stunning. We just went for drinks and they took care of us (other places nearby are stuffy and force everyone to buy an entree for you to buy a drink). We tried the cocktails Sandia, Loco Blanco, Godfather. All three were great.

The service was impeccableâattentive, friendly, without hovering. Everyone was pleasant. The view is unforgettable. Overlooking the ZÃ³calo at night is magical and adds an extra layer of charm to the whole experience.

I canât wait to come back to enjoy everything BalcÃ³n del ZÃ³calo has to offer again. Highly recommend it for a special evening out or just treating yourself to a fantastic meal and drinks!

---

text: Newer taco restaurant  on Tejon just north of Cimarron. The restaurant is big and has a nice relaxed atmosphere. I did not get to dine in, but sat at the bar while waiting for my order. I watch the bartenders make margaritas and they looked great, unfortunately, I had to drive home so didn't try any.  The menu has a large variety of tacos to choose from.  I ordered 6 different tacos to go (since it was my first time trying them, I wanted to sample as many as possible).  The tacos transported well and were quite tasty. I am sure eating them at the restaurant would have been a far better experience. I also ordered the churros.  They transported well, were still pretty warm with a nice chewy interior and a crispy exterior.  I will definitely be going back.

text:
I was very disappointed from my experience. I have thought about my review for two months.

The initial complication started with the order to order a taco. I had questions. She didn't understand my simple questions about the ingredients of the specific tacos I was inquiring about (the vegetarian options). Ultimately, I wanted to know what the ingredients were and if it was free of animal products. My friend and I were able to decipher that she didn't know. When she came back to bring my friend's queso, and to take her order, I had a couple more questions about customizing my order. The server just couldn't comprehend. I tried four times to ask my questions. To restate my questions. Rephrase my questions and then I thought maybe I am not speaking well enough. So, my friend, who's a very articulate and great at projecting rephrased and reframe exactly what I was asking. No, there was not a a language barrier.

The request was to remove one ingredient from a taco. Or option 2, was was to apply the Portabella mushroom  mushroom to a different taco as the protein. It blew her mind. Following the conversation about customizing the taco I just gave up.  She went to go ask somebody in the kitchen. I don't even think she knew what she was asking. Even if she asked. While she was away, I asked my friend if I was not speaking clearly, or how I could've worded that more clearly and more understandable. She said, I think you were very clear.

The server returned. I wanted to make this a simple for everybody.  I will order the portobello taco with no cheese or creama. When the food arrived. Of course, there was creama on the taco. Yet the cheese was not present. Close, but still deadly. They remade the taco.

My incomprehensible request was the CAMOTE AL PASTOR taco with the Portabella mushroom added as a protein. That's all.

I ended up with the PANELA MUSHROOM, no cheese and creama.

While are they prepared our tacos, I noticed the water glass had red lipstick on it. As a result, I took a closer look. It was unwashed. Completely. Fingerprints and all. At this point I drank almost half of the water. Note, the server was very gracious, embarrassed and apologetic. They replaced my right away. Yes this can happen. It's disgusting. I'm not sure how it happened. At this point, I was really hopeful that the food redeem this place. Because the ambience was great, aside from the loud music.

When the mushroom taco arrived, it was simply a mushroom, with sauce, arugula on a tortilla. I asked for a side of avocado slices. She brings me smashed avocado, which they call guacamole. Which is OK. I just needed something to add flavor and a little more value to my taco. The flavor didn't change much. And I love avocado.

They did not charge me for the Avocado/guacamole due to the dirty water glass. That's very much appreciated. And I want to acknowledge that.

What's a taco good? No. Was it filling? No. It was lacking density and flavor. Also substance. I would love to have ordered more, but I was not going to even try based on the in accuracy and the lack of flavor or taste. I just left hungry.

My friend did enjoy her chips and queso. Her toco was "okay" as it lacked flavor. I don't recall which taco she ordered but it was an animal protein taco.

That taco isn't worth of five dollars. That taco isn't worth $1.50.

You will leave smelling like tacos. My coworkers new I had tacos for lunch. From two offices from away, he smelled me and my clothes. It's not a bad smell, but in a modern restaurant I don't think I should smell like a taco shop..

I do not recommend this place. I have no plans of going back. Many other people have had a very different experiences than I.

I don't understand, due to the computer in her hand, and from her knowledge, she could not request that the Portabella mushroom be added to a taco.  Perhaps the training gap. But also, you can add a note that says side of Portabella mushroom. Or place Portabella mushroom on this taco. No effort.
dominant_topics_words: nice, great, amazing, place, food, food, service, bad, tacos, order

text:
One Star. Great View, Terrible Food

We were excited to try BalcÃ³n del ZÃ³calo based on the views and the buzz online, but this turned out to be one of the worst dining experiences weâve had in Mexico City.

The space itself is beautiful, and the staff were friendly when we arrived, but unfortunately thatâs where the positives end. The food was a major letdown, and thatâs putting it lightly. Even for a group of adventurous eaters, the flavor combinations were strange and didnât work. A standout oddity: no real butter, just a strange coffee butter. But the real issue came with the steak.

One of our dishes came out completely raw, not rare or even medium-rare. raw. We sent it back immediately, and instead of correcting the issue, they simply removed the plateâ¦ and still charged us full price. No apology, no attempt to make it right.

To make matters worse, we had come specifically because we saw guacamole promoted online only to be told they didnât serve it anymore.

We even spoke with other diners who were equally disappointed with their meals.

Bottom line: go for the view if you must, but skip the food. There are so many incredible dining options in CDMX. this is not one of them.

text: Your house!

text:
Constitution Square, also known as the ZÃ³calo, is an iconic location in the heart of Mexico City. With a rich history spanning from pre-Hispanic times to the present day, this plaza is a reflection of Mexican national identity.

*History and Significance*

- In pre-Hispanic times, the ZÃ³calo was part of the Templo Mayor, an important ceremonial center of the Aztecs.
- After the Spanish conquest, the Plaza Mayor was built, which became the political and religious center of the city.
- In 1813, it was officially named Plaza de la ConstituciÃ³n in honor of the Constitution of CÃ¡diz.
- The name "ZÃ³calo" comes from an unfinished project by Antonio LÃ³pez de Santa Anna to build a monument to Independence in the center of the square. Only the base, or zÃ³calo, was placed, and it remained in place for years.

*Buildings and Monuments*

- *Metropolitan Cathedral*: one of the city's most important churches, built on the ruins of the Aztec Templo Mayor.
- *National Palace*: seat of the federal executive branch, built on the site of Moctezuma's palace.
- *Templo Mayor*: an archaeological site and museum housing the remains of the Aztec civilization.
- *City Hall*: seat of the Mexico City government.

*Current Issues*

- The presence of street vendors in the plaza is a controversial issue, as some believe it affects the aesthetics and functionality of the public space.

In short, the Plaza de la ConstituciÃ³n is an iconic place that reflects Mexico's rich history and culture. Although it faces current challenges, it remains an important political, religious, and cultural center of the city.

Man, screw this place. As a Mexican, I am disappointed of how it is managed. From the top, with all the rain and mess in the city, I dont know why there is not a wardrobe service (at the moment), then the staff is not polite and condescending. So with that out of the way, let me talk about the most annoying part. The booking in advance system only. There is no line up. You may think, ok makes sense. No it doesnât it just allows scalpers to buy tickets and to sell them to 5 times the price through their websites cause they over buy the weekends and other days. I am the first advocate for buying and supporting local, but this is NOT! This system only benefits Booking Viator and other third parties. So, until they update that and allow for walk ins. Id say dont come here. You will have a better experience a few blocks from there at the Trotsky House Museum and a free tour with Daniel.

text: The Frida Kahlo Museum is one of those rare places that leaves you a little changed after visiting. It is not just a museum but the actual home where she lived, created, and endured her setbacks and triumphs. Walking through her rooms and seeing her studio with the brushes still at hand makes you feel as though she just stepped out for a moment. The experience is intimate and moving in a way that no traditional gallery can be because you are not only seeing her art, you are standing in the space where her life unfolded. The exhibits take you through her hardships and resilience, showing how every piece she created was born out of pain, strength, and an almost defiant creativity. The gardens are another highlight, lush and vibrant, a sanctuary that contrasts with the intensity of her story yet feels like a natural extension of her artistry. The tour is well done, guiding you through her world with just enough explanation to deepen the experience without overshadowing it. This is easily a five star cultural destination in Mexico City, worth every minute, and one of those places you carry with you long after leaving.

The food here was the best we have had and great value.
We started with wine all from Mexico. Choices limited however we were happy with our choices. Next we had the salad with bacon and spiced nuts. Tacos we had the fish and octopus. Fish was better. Next steak and fish. The steak was perfectly cooked and the mustard sauce was a perfect compliment.  The fish was very good but the steak was better.  Lastly we had a slight communication lapse where I got the almond ice cream and cream cone and my daughter got the sorbet. text: Oh no, what can I say about my beautiful Puebla, which has given me everything and has also given me everything. It's certainly not a perfect cityâno city isâbut the magic of my city lies in the collision of antiquity with modernity. Quality of life and sustainable living, spectacular climate, and a historic center carved by Mexicans, hundreds of beautiful buildings that, like silent witnesses, have stood before the entire conquest and colonial era of our country. That energy is perceived, felt, and moves me. I am proudly from Puebla. There are undoubtedly shortcomings, but Puebla has a big heart and a mystical energy. Everyone is welcome. Walk around the main square and the surrounding area, eat a lot, take photos, visit the museums and wonders of the world, enjoy the weather, contemplate the volcanoes, enjoy the culture and avant-garde. Just return to your cities after your visit, because there are already so many of us, hehe. Enjoy!

text: Frida Kahlo was a world renowned Mexican artist. This museum is actually in the house where she lived until she passed away. The museum displays some of her works along with a history of her life. A lot of the rooms are left just the way they were while she was living there. She had polio in her childhood and then she had a tragic accident while riding a school bus when a tram crashed into her. She suffered multiple fractures in her hip and spine. She was bedridden for a long time while she recovered from her injuries. She was in constant pain but she had an indomitable spirit to live. She taught herself to paint, initially inspired by her husband and later on her own. She gained recognition worldwide. The pain she endured while she was alive comes through in some of her works. This is a must see museum in Mexico City. The tickets sell out quickly so buy them well in advance.
dominant_topics_words: nice, great, amazing, place, food

text:
A beautiful tour.
It's the most expensive museum in Mexico City (others are around 100 pesos), but it's definitely worth it if you're a fan of Frida's life.
The museum doesn't feature many original works (only replicas), but it does feature excerpts from Frida's diaries and letters. It's an intimate experience of her life and the art of living.

text:
The CN Tower is an iconic part of the Toronto skyline, and a visit here is a must for anyone new to the city. While the price can feel a bit steepâit almost feels like a "daytime robbery" at timesâthe magnificent views you get from the observation decks make it almost worth the expense.
We visited in late August and found the crowd to be moderate. We didn't have to wait in any excessively long lines, and the staff was friendly and efficient, making the whole process easy to navigate. The accessibility is a big plus, and there is plenty of parking available in the area, which takes a lot of stress out of the visit.
From the top, you get a breathtaking panoramic view of the city, Lake Ontario, and beyond. The glass floor is a thrilling experience and a great photo opportunity. Despite the high cost, the views and overall smooth experience make the CN Tower a solid four-star attraction.

text:
They serve them cold, not heated.
The flautas are well-browned, but very dry, lacking visual appeal, and the bite is also unenjoyable. The salsa is served in a small plastic bottle, not in proper containers. The quesadillas are well-browned, and that's it. They have no color or aroma, they don't tell you to order them with cream or cheese... and the salsa is in a bottle, as if it were one of those snack sauces. No, please. You go to TOÃO'S HOUSE... Don't eat at the supermarket! Seriously, the food lacks personality.

dominant_topics_words: excellent, service, place, attention, station

text:
The first 3 to 5 times I ordered, it was tasty, an adequate portion, neither too little nor too much, at a good price, and carefully served.
Now, sometimes I keep ordering, not because I like it or love it, but because it's the least bad.
Also, I don't know if it happens to you, but the more times I order, the more ugly and sloppy they send me. It seems that instead of feeling flattered and committed, it makes them angry that I keep ordering.
The Tupperware arrives stained with marks or fingerprints from cream, salsa, etc. The portions are smaller and more expensive. When I order two pozoles, they send the condiments (lettuce, lemons, onion, etc.) only for one pozole, and once they didn't send anything, just the pozole and tostadas for one. If they don't have them anymore, at least let us know so we know if we still want it or not, or cancel the order promptly.
I really liked ordering chilaquiles with steak, but I stopped ordering them because they were more like skin than meatâpractically skin or tough meat, if you will.
I find the quesadillas very expensive for how small they are.
The flautas sometimes come with a decent portion of chicken and other times with a rough portion.
It's worth mentioning that their menu is practically all tortillas (chilaquiles, enchiladas, flautas, quesadillas, sopes) with decent chicken, but I don't recommend them with steak.
Finally, they raised the prices and reduced the portions.
The tinga (pork) by the gram doesn't say what kind of meat it is; I think it's pork, but they don't mention it, even though they include government-mandated inscriptions, the ingredients are unclear, and their flavor is average, acceptable.
In short, sometimes I keep ordering them, not because I like them or love them, but because they're the least bad.
dominant_topics_words: food, service, bad, tacos, order, pretty, negative, cdmx, delivery, positive
