text:
This is just a review of their red pozole, which is their most popular dish. In general, this chain has decent food (otherwise it wouldn't be so popular) and the prices are low. It's basically one of the cheapest sit-down restaurant chains, but it's trustworthy and consistent.

I had a large red pozole with chicken ($99), and it was served fast and hot, with a generous amount of chicken. However, I highly recommend some lime and a little powdered red pepper. That took the dish from a 3 to a 4.5. There are a ton of servers working there, so just get someone's attention and you will get what you need fast. The interior is bright and clean, but it's utilitarian. Overall good food, good service, and good prices.

text:
We used to go there a lot, but the reality is that the quality of the food has drastically declined. The portions are smaller, the flavor has changed, and the servings are getting smaller.
Drinks have skyrocketed in price, and the takeout service is terrible (they send you a packet of salsa and if you want more, they charge you for it, haha). For the pozole, they sent three lettuce leaves, no lemons, and no additional seasoning, even though we didn't ask for it.

And it's incredibly uncomfortable when, in the rush to welcome so many people, the waiters come to your table every five seconds. From being regular customers, we don't visit anymore.

text:
The King of Pozole and Antojitos: Exquisite Flavor and Amazing Efficiency

La Casa de ToÃ±o, and the AragÃ³n branch in particular, is for me the ultimate place for Mexican antojitos. They've achieved something incredible: bringing the experience of a traditional neighborhood pozoleria to a chain model without sacrificing flavor.

What I love:

The food is a 10/10: The pozole is consistently delicious, with an authentic, comforting flavor. The rest of the antojitos are simply exquisite. They never disappoint.

The Customer Experience: The service is excellent. Their system is so efficient that from the moment you arrive until you leave, everything flows seamlessly. They are fast, attentive, and never fail to deliver.

An important observation:

The Staff's Work Rate: As a customer, I enjoy impeccable service. However, I can't help but notice the immense pressure the team seems to be working under. The waiters and captains move at a breakneck pace without stopping. While this results in amazing efficiency, it leaves me feeling like a lot is being demanded of them. It's a recognition of the enormous effort they put in.

In short:

The dining experience is first-class, and I always leave more than satisfied. It's my go-to spot when I'm craving Mexican food. Highly recommended!

text:
One of Mexico City's most iconic buildings, the historic Palacio de Bellas Artes (Palace of Fine Arts) hosts ongoing temporary exhibitions, such as this one featuring "The Impressionist Revolution from Monet to Matisse" at the Palace Museum. The cost is $95.00 Mexican pesos per person; students with ID receive a discount. There are museum and palace shops, and there's a small parking lot in the basement.
It truly is one of the few places so accessible to everyone and where we can enjoy world-class exhibitions.
It's a place everyone should visit at least once a year!

text: Views of Toronto. You can see "Toronto in its entirety." We bought tickets in advance for the first and upper levels. If you're short on time, the first level is sufficient. I recommend buying tickets in advance. If the CN Tower website isn't working for you, don't worry; it happens often. Send an email stating that you weren't able to purchase tickets online and detailing the type of tickets you want, for what day and time, and whose name, etc. They'll respond quickly and will have them stored in one of the ticket booths. You'll pay when you pick them up and you'll have skipped one of the lines. Tell the staff there, showing them the response (email), and they'll tell you where to pick them up and get in line.

text:
So, I've been stewing on this since Saturday when we went to The R.O.M. for the first time. We (myself, my husband, our adult kids  with one spouse and our granddaughter)  drove almost 3 hours specifically to see the Auschwitz exhibit. Something that is near to my heart because my Nana was a Polish slave during WWII .
We continously checked the website on our way there to make sure time slots were available and at no time did it give any indication the time slots were getting full.
We arrived shortly before 1 p.m. and were advised all time slots were full except 3:40 p.m. .
The person who was helping us purchase tickets for that slot also told us there were only 2 available for that time. But, advised us it was OK. There would be no problem having 4 extra people. He also advised us our best bet was to buy the tickets that allowed us into the other exhibit, the Flemish 300 years of art exhibit.  Assuring us we would have time for both.
We proceeded to buy those tickets to the tune of almost 200 dollars.
He advised us to browse the other areas of the museum (several areas blocked off due to exhibit updates etc). We enjoyed what we were able to see and approximately 30 mins before our alloted time to visit the Auschwitz exhibit made our way back to the elevators to go to that floor.
We were met with a mess. People crowded into the area by the elevators. No one knew where to be. Workers blocking the elevators saying we were unable to go up yet and virtually everyone saying they had tickets for 3:40.
Eventually we were corralled into a line and stood in that line well beyond our alloted time ( 4:40 before we even made it to the elevator. All the while being offered tickets to come another day because *we didn't expect so many people* by museum staff wandering through the line. Interestingly enough we were encouraged to complain to management by these same  staff members.
When we finally got to the entrance of the display it was beyond hot. People were crammed into a small area to wait to get beyond the waiting area.
Once inside there was very little time to actually look at anything before people were being herded in behind us. We spent most of our time waiting for the crowd ahead of us to move forward.
The displays were sparse and consisted mostly of pictures with a few artifacts .
3/4 of the way through the loudspeaker began announcing the museum was closed. Loudly enough that any information being given on the headsets was drowned out.
So, not only were we unable to take a reasonable amount of time to view this important historical information we were unable to even go to the other exhibit we paid to see.
They did refund our money. They also gave us tickets to see the display we missed out on but after the disorganized mess we were shuttled through,  I hesitate to even attempt the journey.
I have honestly seen better displays and organization at little roadside museums in off the beaten track towns.
So disappointing.
I wanted so very much to love this museum and the exhibit we came specifically to see but definitely did not.
What should have been a journey to see what our Nana lived through left us just hot,  sweaty and not even a little more educated than we were when we arrived.

text:
My family was really looking forward to visiting the ROM and were happy to pay the (expensive) admission fee as there are some interesting areas to explore.

The visit ended in disappointment (and frankly, anger) however, as an exhibition that is very personal to my family, the Auschwitz exhibition, is locked behind a separate entrance fee. It is shameful to gatekeep such an important part of history and should instead be made as accessible as possible to all who are interesting in learning about it, not locked behind an extra ticket tier for more profit.

During our visit it was not even possible to buy another ticket as it was sold out for the day. Awareness of such important (and rightly advertised as ânot so long agoâ by the museum itself) pieces of history should never be for profit.

text: The experience at the Royal Ontario Museum was very good. The collections are fascinating. The best one of all was the dinosaurs one. A couple of opportunities for improvement: 4th. Floor Exhibition had no washrooms. Also, the benches or sitting spaces all across the museum are extremely limited, which can be challenging as you may want to take a little break from time to time. You are allowed to bring your lunch, but the only place to leave your cooler is in the coat check area (for a fee). You are able to re-enter the museum the same day, so we decided to go to McDonald's for lunch, which was 2 mins. away walking. There is paid parking very close by. Great experience, highly recommended.

text:
Saturday, May 31, 3:30 p.m. We visited the Casa ToÃ±o branch located on DÃ­az MirÃ³n, in the Miguel Hidalgo borough. Unlike other branches, this one tends to be less busy, so the wait time was minimal.

As with all Casa ToÃ±o restaurants, the food is good and affordable. That day we tried:
â¢ Steak tacos: very tasty and generous portions for the price.
â¢ Minced pork tostadas: hearty and delicious.
â¢ Potato and cheese quesadilla: highly recommended.
â¢ Dessert: coffee with vanilla concha, also quite good.

The advantages of this place are clear: speed, flavor, and price. You'll rarely find anything negative, although it's true that the dishes are delicious without being extraordinary.

In short: Casa ToÃ±o is a highly recommended place for any time of day, whether breakfast, lunch, or dinner. Delicious, fast, and affordable foodâa formula that's hard to fail.

text:
It is a good place to go to eat a rich Mexican pozole accompanied by some tasty flautas which can be assorted or can be the three of the same selection of taste and these can be normal or drowned in a variety of sauces which in my opinion do not sting, but they always put different types of sauces on the table for tasting, I recommend the guacamole which they put in a bottle on the table, and this is not charged.

For dessert I highly recommend the flan de cajeta de la abuela and for drinks there is a great variety from aguas frescas, soft drinks to beers. I recommend the place because the service is quite fast, maybe at the reception you can wait up to 10 minutes but once you are inside the service is fast, so I suggest by education in Mexico leave at least 10% tip as a basis, this varies depending on the service you receive from the waiters.

If you are a foreigner and want to try Mexican cuisine I recommend this place, it is nice, good and cheap.

text:
I placed an order through La Casa de ToÃ±o's new WhatsApp system, since they are no longer available on Rappi or Uber Eats. I followed all the steps: I shared my location in real time and wrote my full address, which was confirmed by their team. Until then, everything is correct.

I received a tracking link through Uber, but when the delivery driver left I noticed that they sent the order to the wrong address. I contacted the delivery person, but he told me that he could not change the address and that I had to deliver it as is. If I cannot deliver it, I would return it to the restaurant.

I immediately contacted La Casa de ToÃ±o's WhatsApp service. After much insistence, they told me that I would have to personally go to the branch for the order, that they would only keep it for an hour and that, if I didn't go, they would throw it away. They rejected any type of refund or solution, arguing that this is what their terms and conditions indicate.

The unfair thing is that I did correctly provide my location and address, which was confirmed by them, therefore the "wrong address" policy does not apply. The most disappointing thing was the lack of empathy, real care and solutions. I also called customer service and they told me that they could only assist me through WhatsApp, to repeat the same thing: "There are no refunds or resends."

I recommend being very careful when placing orders via WhatsApp with La Casa de ToÃ±o. Their system has flaws, their service is slow, and in the event of an error they are not responsible, even if the error was theirs.

A big disappointment from a restaurant I used to go to often. I hope they can improve their service and customer service.
dominant_topics_words: food, service, bad, tacos, order

text:
ROM is not friendly to special needs children.

My son has low muscle tone, developmental delays, and is autistic. Upon arrival, we were told to check in our wagon and were offered a stroller as an alternative. Unfortunately, the stroller provided was undersized, causing his feet to drag on the ground. This discomfort triggered sensory issues, prompting him to remove his shoes repeatedly throughout the visit.

We rely on a wagon during outings to carry his essentials such as diapers and water, and to provide a sense of comfort and security. Additionally, it helps reduce the uncomfortable attention he sometimes receives when using a stroller due to his age and size.

What was especially disheartening was seeing other families inside the museum using wagons, which made the situation feel inconsistent and unfair.

Navigating public spaces with a special needs child is already difficult, and we had hoped for a more supportive and inclusive experience.
dominant_topics_words: nice, great, amazing, place, food

text: Beautiful view from this tower! It's a tourist attraction in Toronto. I booked tickets on their website a few days before leaving because I didn't know if we could get seats. text: We visited the CN tower yesterday. Despite not booking ahead, we barely queued to buy our tickets and then go up to the top. Note that we went up towards the end of the afternoon to catch the sunset. Which we did! The different viewpoints are worth it. However, at the beginning of the visit, the Tower staff takes pictures of the visitors as souvenir. We were very surprised to discover at the end of our visit that the pictures were already printed, but that they costed $45 + taxes. If you donât buy them, they get shredded. What a waste of resources! We didnât buy them because of the outrageous price (equivalent to a one-person ticket up the tower). It was very disappointing to end on this note - and to know our smily pictures were about to be shredded.

text: The pozole broth was salty for our taste. I don't know if there is someone who can test the broth's condition before adding corn, etc., and give it to the diner. All the other foods were tasty and very well served, just the pozole broth.

The food is acceptable, but the pozole is their strong point, it could use a little more seasoning. The portion of pozole in their small sizes is more the cost than the size. They could improve, but I don't think they want to. You go to the lady on the corner who sells pozole, and it's definitely better than here. Their service is good, but it gets annoying that every minute someone asks you if you need or want anything else. Keep the interruptions down; it doesn't let you eat or chat comfortably. Just be on the lookout for someone to call you; that's why they have the buzzer on the table, right? Oh! And please, if there are a lot of empty tables and no one around, don't bother us so we can leave as soon as possible. Besides eating, if someone is with someone, we like to chat, okay? Thanks.

text:
Auschwitz Exhibit:
This exhibit was fascinating, thorough, and well thought out. The audio device with headphones was fabulous. The artifacts were thoughtfully chosen, with detailed information about them. The replicas/ and or the actual artifacts were perfectly preserved. The videos/audio gave a lot of life to the exhibit and really demonstrated what happened in Auschwitz to its victims. I especially loved the probably lesser known people, i.e. the carpenter who made a box for the SS after his skills were discovered. I did find the exhibits/displays a bit confusing. It was hard to figure out where to start in each room after the big red signs introducing each room. Before you go, you need to read up on the camps/WW2. I think it would be confusing if you did not know what happened. I don't think it is a place for children-only because of the density of the content. There is a lot of reading, listening, and watching. I spent 3 hours there and I don't think the parents/ adults with kids would get the same kind of experience. Also, the parents/ adults would get distracted with the kids and not focus on the exhibit. What I really found interesting was the silence.....everyone had their headphones on and even in between the audio excerpts, people were quiet. It was a respectful environment and conducive to learning. I do wish there was someone at the end I could have asked questions. It is well worth the trip and the cost.
dominant_topics_words: good, beautiful, place, eat, service, nice, great, amazing, place, food

text:
Overall 4.5 stars.
Many things to go through. Could easily spend 5 hours there. I only spent 3.5 hours cause I got tired. Quick line when I went. There are extra exhibits if you pay a little extra. If you get to go for free it will definitly be fun.

text: A truly versatile collection that can easily make a few hours go by quickly.

I recently had the chance to visit the Royal Ontario Museum (ROM), and it was a truly memorable experience. The museum is massive and beautifully designed, with an impressive infrastructure that immediately captures your attention.
Even though I had only about an hour to explore (as the museum closes at 5:30 PM on Sundays), I was able to see a wide variety of fascinating exhibits. From historical artifacts to species displays, crystals, diaspores, and cultural history exhibits, there was so much to take in. The museum does a great job of curating items from different time periods and parts of the world, offering a rich blend of natural history, art, and culture.
One hour was definitely not enough to explore everything thoroughlyâthis is the kind of place you could easily spend half a day in if you're someone who enjoys history, science, and art. Iâd highly recommend arriving earlier in the day to make the most of your visit.
Whether you're a tourist or a local, the ROM is absolutely worth visiting at least once. It's educational, inspiring, and a great place to appreciate the beauty and depth of human and natural history.
dominant_topics_words: nice, great, amazing, place, food, food, service, bad, tacos, order, service, fast, delicious, food, good

text: The Royal Ontario Museum is a must-visit in Toronto. The exhibits are diverse and impressive, ranging from natural history to art and culture. Plan to spend a few hours here to explore properly!

text: Not only has my family been members on and off over the years (as we do try to join various Toronto organizations) but as my kids have grown, so too have their various interests, and our 'floors' and events visited. Recently was unable to book a slot for the Auschwitz Installation (user error no doubt) and within movements of sending my email for clarity, I was sent two tickets and a modest apology. This happened also when we sought clarity on our membership email once.  It's good to know that if you support an organization they will do a FANTASTIC job of supporting you.

text:
This is the landmark telecommunications tower and tourist attraction in the city centre of Toronto. It was constructed between 1973-75 and at 553 metres in height was the tallest freestanding structure in the world until 2007. The CN Tower dominates the Toronto skyline and can be viewed fairly well throughout the city.

Visitors have sightseeing and dining opportunities at the CN Tower. The Observation level is open from 9am to 11pm daily. Timed tickets start at CND$45 per adult and can be reserved online in advance or purchased on the day at the ticketing office. Adventure travellers can also try the Edgewalk attraction while diners have several eatery options including a sit down restaurant with 360 degree views of the city. The restaurant opening hours are 11.30am to 3pm (lunch) and 4.30pm to 10pm (dinner) daily.

text: The Palace of Fine Arts is one of those places that always impresses me, no matter how many times I visit. From the outside, its architecture is imposing, with that mix of white marble and details that make it unique in the city. Inside, murals by artists like Diego Rivera and Siqueiros give it an enormous cultural power, and every corner seems to tell a part of Mexico's history. What I enjoy most is that it's not just a museum; it's also a living space that hosts concerts, operas, and various shows. Being there gives me a sense of pride and connection to the culture, because it represents the best of Mexican art and creativity.

text:
Alhamdulillah,
Excited to share about the Royal Ontario Museum (ROM) in Toronto! ð¨ð¦

This is a special moment in my journey of exploring the worldâs history and culture.

Founded in 1914, the Royal Ontario Museum is one of North Americaâs largest museums, dedicated to natural history, world cultures, and art. Over the decades, ROM has become a hub for learning, research, and global heritage, attracting millions of visitors every year. Its Michael Lee-Chin Crystal, a modern architectural addition, beautifully blends contemporary design with historical elegance.

From the Australian art galleries that inspired creativity,
to the Hiroshima Peace Memorial that taught reflection and hope,
and the Auckland War Museum that honored bravery and history,
each visit has enriched my perspective.

Now, ROM adds a Canadian chapter with its amazing artifacts, dinosaur skeletons, and world cultures. Its treasures and iconic architecture make it a must-visit for anyone passionate about history and art.

Every museum I visit connects me more deeply to human creativity, resilience, and heritage.

Canât wait to explore and learn more!

text: recent visitor to Museum.  Attended Auschwitz exhibit expected to be impressed with presentation.  Was surprised at how very much toned down to almost a first grade presentation of the events.  Not shocking, not a presentation that one would feel bad.  Don't like using the word other than toned down.  Lacking shock value.  The current generation should be told the truth and not something that is so very much watered down.  I felt even some academic censorship of the subject was presented.  Sad to see.  Would not recommend any other institution use this exhibit that is far, far too tame.  Did not give any sense of the horror of this location or of the events.  Where were the photos or films of corpses and bodies discovered by the Russian army?  None of this was presented and should have been at the very least.

text: I arrived that ROM after an unexpected long walk from the Museum subway station not feeling well at all. I'm a senior and  the staff on the floor especially a security guard called Mara was extremely kind and helpful during my experience. She got me a wheelchair that my daughter pushed me around in, and I got to see the exhibits that I do specifically came down to Toronto to see. I cannot say enough for her help. And at the end of the day when we were leaving, she again was there to say goodbye and we had a good chuckle at my experience, but she definitely made my day better. The museum itself is fantastic. And while it would probably be the last time I will come here due to the distance that I live from the Toronto I have thoroughly enjoyed visiting here over the last seventy years.

In my opinion, it is not a place whose fame guarantees excellent service, quality and price. The food is expensive and not exactly the best. It is annoying that they charge you for everything extra. The flautas, which was what I ordered, were stuffed with lettuce, cream and cheese, but I had the impression that they were frozen and were not very good. The water was expensive compared to the quantity; you would have to order two or three glasses. The pozole was of average quality, with no differentiator compared to a pozole from the Garibaldi or Morelos markets.
